1996 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|1996 Atlanta]]|[[Serbia national basketball team|FR Yugoslavia]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIBA World Cup]]}} {{MedalGold|[[2002 FIBA World Championship|2002 USA]]|FR Yugoslavia}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIBA EuroBasket]]}} {{MedalGold|[[1995 EuroBasket|1995 Greece]]|FR Yugoslavia}} {{MedalBronze|[[1999 EuroBasket|1999 France]]|FR Yugoslavia}} }} '''Vlade Divac''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Владе Дивац}}, {{IPA-sh|ʋlǎːde dǐːʋats|pron}}; born February 3, 1968) is a Serbian professional basketball executive and retired player, currently serving as the vice president of basketball operations and general manager of the [[Sacramento Kings]].<ref name="divac-gm"/>
Divac spent most of his career in the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). At {{nowrap|7 ft 1 in}}, he played [[center (basketball)|center]] and was known for his passing skills. He was among the first group of European basketball players to transfer to the NBA in the late 1980s and was named one of the [[50 Greatest EuroLeague Contributors]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.euroleague.net/item/24016 |title=Experts decide European Club Basketball's 50 greatest contributors – 50 YEARS – Welcome to EUROLEAGUE BASKETBALL |publisher=Euroleague.net |date= |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref> He is one of seven players in NBA history to record 13,000 [[Point (basketball)|points]], 9,000 [[Rebound (basketball)|rebounds]], 3,000 [[Assist (basketball)|assists]] and 1,500 blocked shots, along with [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]], [[Tim Duncan]], [[Shaquille O'Neal]], [[Kevin Garnett]], [[Pau Gasol]], and [[Hakeem Olajuwon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/divac_retires_051018.html |title=Vlade Divac Announces Retirement; Accepts Position With Lakers &#124|publisher=Nba.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref><ref group=n>The NBA did not record blocked shots before the 1973–74 season, so earlier players such as [[Bill Russell]] and [[Wilt Chamberlain]] probably had similar career achievements.</ref> Divac was also the first player born and trained outside the United States to play in over 1,000 games in the NBA. On August 20, 2010, he was inducted into the [[FIBA Hall of Fame]] in recognition of his play in international competition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.halloffame.fiba.com/pages/eng/hof/news/p/newsid/42798/arti.html |title=FIBA announces 2010 Hall of Fame Class |publisher=[[FIBA]] |date=2010-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101019073536/http://www.halloffame.fiba.com/pages/eng/hof/news/p/newsid/42798/arti.html |archivedate=2010-10-19 |df= }}</ref>
Aside from being noticed for his basketball abilities, Divac is also known as a humanitarian, helping children in his native country of Serbia, and in Africa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/news/divac_youcantoo_070922.html |title=Divac Creates New Team With "You Can Too" Campaign |publisher=NBA.com |date=2007-09-22 |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref> In October 2008, he was appointed as government adviser in Serbia for humanitarian issues.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nba/news?slug=ap-divac-serbianadviser&prov=ap&type=lgns |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-10-17 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081020220122/http://sports.yahoo.com/nba/news?slug=ap-divac-serbianadviser&prov=ap&type=lgns |archivedate=October 20, 2008 |df= }}</ref> In February 2009, he was elected President of the [[Serbian Olympic Committee]] for a 4-year term <ref name="blicokserb">{{cite web |url=http://www.blic.rs/sport.php?id=80659 |title=Divac na čelu OKS naredne četiri godine |language=Serbian |date=2009-02-24 |publisher=Blic |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090227115052/http://www.blic.rs/sport.php?id=80659 |archivedate=2009-02-27 |df= }}</ref> and re-elected in November 2012.<ref name=oks>{{cite web|url=http://sport.blic.rs/Ostali-sportovi/223132/Divac-ponovo-izabran-za-predsednika-Olimpijskog-komiteta-Srbije |title=Vlade Divac ponovo izabran za predsednika Olimpijskog komiteta |language=Serbian |trans-title=Vlade Divac re-elected for the President of the Olympic Committee|publisher=Beta |date= November 7, 2012}}</ref> In 2013, Divac received an honor from the World Sports Humanitarian Hall of Fame.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/kings/news/divac_hall_of_fame08.html |title=Kings News Full | The Official Site Of The Sacramento Kings |publisher=Nba.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref>
==Club playing career== Divac began playing basketball in his home town [[Prijepolje]] for the team KK Elan. He began his professional career in Yugoslavia playing for [[KK Sloga|Sloga]] from [[Kraljevo]], and was immediately noted for scoring 27 points against [[KK Crvena zvezda|Crvena zvezda]].<ref name="vreme">{{cite web |url=http://www.vreme.com/cms/view.php?id=512456 |title=Srbin broj jedan van Srbije |publisher=[[Vreme]] |date=2007-09-20 |author=Slobodan Georgijev |language=Serbian}}</ref>
===KK Partizan=== In the summer of 1986, Divac was the top star of the basketball transfer season, and he ended up signing with [[KK Partizan|Partizan]] for [[Deutsche Mark|DM]]14,000.<ref name="vreme" />
In the [[1986–87 Yugoslav First Basketball League|1986–87 Yugoslav First League season]], with players like Divac, [[Aleksandar Đorđević]], [[Žarko Paspalj]], [[Željko Obradović]], and with [[head coach|coach]] [[Duško Vujošević]] at the helm, Partizan had a "dream team", which won the [[Yugoslavian First Federal Basketball League|Yugoslavian League]] title. In the subsequent [[1987–88 FIBA European Champions Cup|1987–88 FIBA European Champions Cup season]] (now called EuroLeague), the club failed to reach the top of the [[EuroLeague]], after having lost to [[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]] in [[1988 EuroLeague Final Four|the semifinal in Ghent]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stat.co.rs/partizan/eng/istorijat.php |title=Istorija: Novi "Dream Team" |publisher=[[KK Partizan|Partizan]] official website |accessdate=2007-09-24}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> [[KK Split|Jugoplastika]], with [[Dino Rađa]] and [[Toni Kukoč]], was a stronger team in the subsequent three years, reigning both in Yugoslavia and in Europe.
Divac had an unusual style compared to most other [[center (basketball)|centers]] of his generation: despite his height, he possessed good mobility, had good control of the ball, and was a decent shooter. On occasion, he would also act as a [[point guard|play maker]]. His trademark moves included a mid-range shot at the top of the key and flip shots around the rim, while facing the complete opposite direction. His quirky moves complemented how he liked playing gags on the court: in the [[1989 EuroBasket]], he lifted teammate [[Zoran Radović]] for a [[slam dunk]]. In just four professional seasons in Europe, he became the most sought-after big man on the continent, after [[Arvydas Sabonis]].<ref name="vreme" />
===Los Angeles Lakers=== Drafted into the NBA in [[1989 NBA draft|1989]] by the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], Divac became one of the first European players to have an impact in the league. Under the mentorship of [[Kareem Abdul-Jabbar]] and [[Magic Johnson]], he improved his play and adapted to the American style of basketball. Though he spoke no English, he quickly became popular among his teammates and the public for his charm and joviality. In the 1989–90 season, he was selected into the [[NBA All-Rookie Team]].<ref name="vreme" />
Divac earned a reputation for [[flop (basketball)|flopping]], or deceiving the officials into calling a foul on the other team by purposely falling to the floor upon contact with an opposing player.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/columnists/orl-nbainsider2807jan28,0,6686181.column?track=rss |title=Shutting down acting school? |author=Tim Povtak |work=Orlando Sentinel |date=2007-01-28 |accessdate=2007-04-29}}</ref> Veteran NBA forward [[P. J. Brown]] claimed that Divac might have been the best of all time at flopping.<ref>[http://www.azcentral.com/sports/suns/articles/0318nbaflop0318.html Flopping keeps cropping up], by Doug Haller, ''The Arizona Republic'', published March 18, 2007, retrieved April 29, 2007</ref> Divac freely admitted doing so, adding that he usually did it when he felt like the officials had missed some calls and owed him.<ref>[http://www.thefreelibrary.com/BEST+ACTOR:+DIVAC+IN+%60FLOP+WARS+II'-a086219289 BEST ACTOR: DIVAC IN `FLOP WARS II'], by Kevin Modesti, Los Angeles ''Daily News'', published May 22, 2002</ref> However, when the NBA instituted anti-flopping penalties in 2012, Divac expressed his support for such rules, stating that he felt players after him were "overdo[ing] it" with respect to flopping.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/kings/2015/03/10/vlade-divac-sacramento-front-office-vivek-ranadive-flopping-lakers-kobe-bryant/24666243/|title=Even Vlade Divac thinks flopping has gotten out of hand|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref> Ian Thomsen, a ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' columnist, grouped Divac with fellow international players [[Anderson Varejão]] and [[Manu Ginóbili]] as the players who "made [flopping] famous", exaggerating contact on the court in a manner analogous to [[diving (football)|diving]] in [[FIFA]] games.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/writers/ian_thomsen/09/28/nba-flopping-david-stern/ | title= NBA's new flopping policy the best response to a difficult problem | date= September 28, 2012 | first= Ian |last= Thomsen |work= [[Sports Illustrated]] | publisher= cnn.com| accessdate=2012-09-28| quote= The ugly trend of faking physical contact began in soccer, a sport in which gamesmanship has given way to players writhing in false agony around the world. Soccer has been unable to fix its problem, but now the NBA will have an opportunity to deter players from trying to simulate violent contact in ways made famous by Vlade Divac, Manu Ginobili and Anderson Varejao.}}</ref>
===Charlotte Hornets=== On July 1, 1996, Divac was traded to the [[Charlotte Hornets]] for the draft rights to [[Kobe Bryant]] and played two seasons there until signing with the Sacramento Kings in July 1998.
===Two games with KK Crvena zvezda=== During the [[1998–99 NBA lockout]], in January 1999, Divac played 2 games for Partizan's [[Eternal derby (Serbia)|eternal rival]] [[KK Crvena Zvezda]], in the [[1998–99 FIBA EuroLeague|1998–99 EuroLeague season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_KNce8jInH7Qj1EsyH5rjn2.compID_,Uz02qBnJiADOq5VntEf53.roundID_2570.season_1999.teamID_1490.playerID_2626.html |title=profile |publisher=Fibaeurope.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref>
His debut for the ''crveno-beli'' took place mid-season, on [[Orthodox Christmas]], versus a heavily favoured [[BC Žalgiris|Žalgiris]] side led by [[Tyus Edney]], [[Mindaugas Žukauskas]], [[Saulius Štombergas]], and [[George Zidek|Jiří Zídek Jr.]]. Supported by a raucous home crowd and energized by Divac's arrival, as well as his 16 points and 8 rebounds, Crvena zvezda pulled off a 77-69 memorable upset win.<ref name="mondo-feb-2015">{{cite news|url=http://mondo.rs/a767526/Sport/Kosarka/Zvezda-Zalgiris-secanje-na-debi-Vlade-Divca.html|title=Prošli put protiv Žalgirisa za Zvezdu je igrao...|agency=mondo.rs|date=4 February 2015|accessdate=4 February 2015}}</ref>
Divac's brief stint with Crvena zvezda, for which he reportedly got paid US$250,000 per game,<ref name="mondo-feb-2015"/> immediately became a sore point with KK Partizan fans, who unfurled a banner calling him a traitor, at their club's next game.<ref name="mondo-feb-2015"/>
The issue of playing for the hated cross-town rival reignited several years later, when Divac returned to KK Partizan as club president. At the time, he stated his decision to play for Crvena zvezda was "a mistake".<ref name="mondo-feb-2015"/>
===Sacramento Kings=== He then signed as a [[free agent]] with the [[Sacramento Kings]] where he played for six seasons alongside fellow countryman [[Peja Stojaković]]. Teamed with Stojaković, [[Hedo Türkoğlu]], [[Chris Webber]] and [[Mike Bibby]]; Divac revitalized the [[Sacramento Kings]] franchise. The Kings rose in the NBA ranks, becoming a perennial playoff contender and eventually a championship contender, leading the league in wins in [[2001–02 NBA season|2001–02]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/standings?season=2002&group=league&seasontype=2&standType=standings |title=NBA Standings – 2001–2002 |publisher=Sports.espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref> The Kings, however, could not get past the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], who beat them in a [[2002 NBA Playoffs#Conference Finals|7-game series in 2002.]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/basketball/ex-referee-tim-donaghy-blows-whistle-nba-dirty-secrets-article-1.293192|title=Ex-referee Tim Donaghy blows whistle on NBA dirty secrets|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref>
===Return to the Lakers=== After the [[2003–04 NBA season]], Divac became a [[free agent]]. He signed a deal to return to the Lakers, part of [[Mitch Kupchak]]'s plan to overhaul Laker basketball. The Lakers, following a defeat in the NBA Finals, had traded away or released most of their players, including [[Shaquille O'Neal]], [[Gary Payton]], [[Karl Malone]], [[Derek Fisher]], and more; Divac was supposed to help fill that void.
However, Divac suffered back problems and could not play most of the season, and even when he returned, could only play about nine minutes per game, averaging 2.3 points per game and 2.1 rebounds per game in 15 games, he played 8 games early in the season and 7 more in the final month of the season.
On 14 July 2005, 37-year-old Divac announced his retirement, ending his sixteen-year NBA and twenty-two-year professional basketball career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/lakers/news/divac_retires_051018.html|title=Vlade Divac Announces Retirement; Accepts Position With Lakers - THE OFFICIAL SITE OF THE LOS ANGELES LAKERS|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref> Divac accepted a position with the Lakers as a European liaison to help with scouting overseas.
===Retirement=== The Kings retired his No. 21 jersey in a ceremony on March 31, 2009.<ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090401/ap_on_sp_bk_ne/bkn_kings_divac_honored;_ylt=An5HUchghgZmP09wgS_FjaILMxIF Kings retire Divac's No. 21 Jersey]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Yahoo! Sports, March 31, 2009</ref> Over his 16 years in the NBA, Divac earned over $93,000,000 in salary.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/d/divacvl01.html |title=Vlade Divac NBA & ABA Stats |publisher=Basketball-Reference.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref> In September 2009, he played for the "NBA Generations" team in the 2009 NBA Asia Challenge, a series of exhibitions against [[Korean Basketball League]] and [[Philippine Basketball Association]] players.<ref>{{cite web|title=NBA Asia Challenge 2009|url=http://www.nba.com/asiachallenge2009/|website=NBA.com|accessdate=21 April 2015}}</ref>
==National team== [[File:Vlade Divac & Drazen Petrovic in Argentina 1990.jpg|thumb|right|170px|Divac with [[Dražen Petrović]] in the [[1990 FIBA World Championship]] held in Argentina.]]
In summer 1986, at 18, right after signing for KK Partizan, Divac debuted for the senior [[Yugoslavia national basketball team]] at the [[1986 FIBA World Championship]] in Madrid, on invitation by the head coach [[Krešimir Ćosić]]. However, the excellent rookie's performance was spoiled by the event in the semi-finals against the [[Soviet Union national basketball team|Soviet Union]]. Forty-five seconds before the end, Yugoslavia had a comfortable lead of 9 points, but the Soviets scored two three-pointers within a few seconds and cut the difference to 3 points. Yugoslavia tried to hold the ball for the remaining time, opting to continue the play with throw-ins instead of free throws following fouls, but with only 14 seconds left, Divac committed a [[double dribble]], the Soviets were awarded the ball, and tied the score with another three-pointer. In the overtime, the Soviets easily prevailed against the shocked Yugoslavs, who had to be content with the bronze.<ref name="vreme" />
The next year, Divac participated in the team that took the gold at the FIBA Junior World Championship (since split into separate [[FIBA Under-19 World Championship|under-19]] and [[FIBA Under-21 World Championship|under-21]] events) in [[Bormio]], Italy. That event launched the young generation of Yugoslavian basket ballers, also featuring stars like Rađa and Kukoč, regarded as likely the best in history. Before the [[breakup of Yugoslavia]], they would also take the titles at [[EuroBasket 1989]] and the [[1990 FIBA World Championship]] in [[Argentina]],<ref name="vreme" /> where they were led by [[Dražen Petrović]],<ref name="fiba1989">{{cite web |url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_KNce8jInH7Qj1EsyH5rjn2.teamID_390.compID_qMRZdYCZI6EoANOrUf9le2.season_1989.roundID_938.html |title=Eurobasket 1989 |publisher=[[FIBA]]}}</ref> as well as the [[EuroBasket 1991]] title, with [[Aleksandar Đorđević]] at [[point guard]].<ref name="fiba1991">{{cite web | url=http://www.fibaeurope.com/cid_KNce8jInH7Qj1EsyH5rjn2.teamID_390.compID_qMRZdYCZI6EoANOrUf9le2.season_1991.roundID_2263.html |title=Eurobasket 1991 |publisher=[[FIBA]]}}</ref>
[[File:Yugoslavia 1990 basketball.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Divac (fourth from right, at centre) with the [[Yugoslavia national basketball team|Yugoslavia team]] that won the [[EuroBasket 1989]].]] When Yugoslavia won the gold in the [[1990 FIBA World Championship]], fans rushed onto the court. One of them was holding a [[Croatia]]n flag, one of the six republics that made up Yugoslavia. Divac claims that he told the man that he should not be waving that flag, since this was a win for Yugoslavia. Divac claims the man made a derogatory remark about the Yugoslav flag, at which point Divac took his flag from him. This happened during a very tense time where nationalistic pride was threatening to tear Yugoslavia apart and ignite a war. The taking of the flag made Divac a hero to Serbs, and a villain to Croatians. Divac has stated that he did not mean it as an act against Croatia and he would have taken away a Serbian flag if a Serb fan had done the same.<ref name=once>{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/once-brothers,46215/| title=Once Brothers |publisher=A. V. club |author=Scott Tobias |date=2010-10-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/oct/12/entertainment/la-et-vlade-divac-20101012 |title=Television review: Vlade Divac searches for closure in ESPN's 'Once Brothers' |publisher=LA Times |author=John Scheibe |date=2010-12-10}}</ref>
This action, along with the [[Yugoslav Wars]], alienated Divac from many of his former Croatian friends, particularly [[Dražen Petrović]], whom he considered his best friend.<ref name=once/> When Yugoslavia won [[EuroBasket 1995]], and [[Croatia national basketball team|Croatia]] won bronze, Croatia, still at [[War in Croatia|war with Serbs from Croatia]], walked off the podium during the medal ceremony. The teams had not faced each other in the tournament.

==Major career achievements==
===KK Partizan=== * [[Yugoslav Basketball League|Yugoslav League]] Champion: ([[1986–87 Yugoslav First Basketball League|1987]]) * [[1988 EuroLeague Final Four]]: 3rd Place * [[Yugoslav Basketball Cup|Yugoslav Cup]] Winner: (1989) * [[FIBA Korać Cup|Korać Cup]] Winner: ([[1988–89 FIBA Korać Cup|1989]])
===Yugoslavia national team=== * Earned gold medal with Yugoslavia's under-18 nationals at the [[1985 FIBA Europe Under-16 Championship]] in [[Rousse]], [[Bulgaria]] * Earned gold medal with Yugoslavia's under-21 nationals at the [[1986 FIBA Europe Under-18 Championship]] in [[Gmunden]], Austria * Earned gold medal with Yugoslavia's under-21 nationals at the 1987 [[FIBA Under-19 World Cup]] in [[Bormio]], Italy, defeating the U.S. team twice in that tournament * Earned silver medals in [[Basketball at the 1988 Summer Olympics|1988 Summer Olympic Games]] (for [[Yugoslavian national basketball team|SFR Yugoslavia]]) and [[Basketball at the 1996 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|1996 Summer Olympic Games]] (for [[FR Yugoslavia national basketball team|FR Yugoslavia]]) * Earned gold medals with [[Yugoslavian national basketball team|SFRY]] at the [[1990 FIBA World Championship]] ([[Argentina]]) and with [[FR Yugoslavia national basketball team|FRY]] at the [[2002 FIBA World Championship]] (U.S.) * Earned gold medals at [[EuroBasket]] in [[EuroBasket 1989|Zagreb 1989]], and [[EuroBasket 1991|Rome 1991]] (with [[Yugoslavian national basketball team|SFRY]]), and in [[EuroBasket 1995|Athens 1995]] (with [[FR Yugoslavia national basketball team|FRY]])
===NBA=== * Named to the 1989–90 NBA All-Rookie First Team after averaging 8.5 ppg and 6.2 rpg for the Lakers * Appeared in the 1991 NBA Finals against the Chicago Bulls and averaged 12.1 ppg, 7.5 rpg and 2.4 apg in 121 career NBA Playoff games * Ranks 4th in Lakers franchise history with 830 blocked shots * Ranked 2nd on the Kings in scoring (14.3 ppg), rebounds (10.0 rpg, 10th in the NBA), assists (4.3 apg) and blocked shots (1.02 bpg) in 1998–99 * Ranked 12th in the NBA in field-goal percentage (.503) in 1999–2000 * Named NBA All-Star, 2001 * One of only five basketball players born and trained in Europe to [[List of National Basketball Association players with 1000 games played|play at least 1,000 NBA games]] (1,134; along with [[Dirk Nowitzki]], [[Tony Parker]], [[Pau Gasol]], [[Boris Diaw]]) * One of only four basketball players born and trained in Europe ([[Peja Stojaković]], [[Dražen Petrović]] and [[Zydrunas Ilgauskas]] are the others) to have his number retired by an NBA team
==Administrative career== Through the twilight of his playing career and afterwards, Divac focused on three fields: humanitarian work, sport management, and investment.
===KK Partizan president=== In late 2000, following the [[overthrow of Slobodan Milošević]] whose policies Divac had been openly critical of throughout mid-to-late 1990s,<ref name="si-may1999-Rick Reilly">{{cite web|url=https://www.si.com/vault/1999/05/24/261148/vlade-divacs-private-war |title=Vlade Divac's Private War |work=[[Sports Illustrated]] |date=1999-05-24 |author=[[Rick Reilly]]}}</ref> Divac and former teammate [[Predrag Danilović]] took over their former club [[KK Partizan]]. They did so on initiative by [[Ivica Dačić]], the club's outgoing president and, more importantly, a suddenly marginalized politician who, due to his association with Milošević, was forced to leave his post at the club. Seeing that various state-owned companies and community property were being taken over in a dubious manner during the power vacuum that resulted from régime change, Dačić saw it prudent to bring the club's two former greats as a safeguard against the same happening to KK Partizan. Divac became the club's president while Danilović took the vice-president role.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blic.rs/Vesti/Politika/61059/Divac-savetuje-Dacica |title=Divac savetuje Dačića |work=[[Blic]] |date=2008-10-16 |author=Ž. Jevtić}}</ref>
Freshly retired from playing, Danilović was actually running the club's day-to-day operations since Divac was still very actively involved with the [[Sacramento Kings]] at the time. The head coach they inherited, [[Darko Russo]], finished out the 2000–01 season before they decided in summer 2001 to bring back their mentor [[Duško Vujošević]] to be the new head coach.
Though the duo never stated so outright, their additional motivation in getting involved with KK Partizan again was perceived to be gaining the upper hand on the club's eventual privatisation process once the new Law on Sports gets passed in the [[National Assembly of Serbia|Serbian parliament]]. Since the exact ownership structure of a publicly owned KK Partizan wasn't and still isn't really clear, potential investors decided to stay away, at least until the law appears. Divac and Danilović appeared pretty much out of nowhere in this regard but enjoyed plenty of fan and public support because most preferred to see their beloved club owned and operated by its former stars rather than a faceless corporation or a group of politicians, managers or businessmen close to the ruling coalition. However, after a few years the duo ran out of patience and pulled out of the venture in late 2004 because it became too much of a financial burden with no end-goal in sight. While he stopped performing any official functions at the club, Divac continued to be involved with it in a lesser capacity for a few years afterwards.
===LA Lakers scout=== In October 2005, right after ending his playing career with the [[Los Angeles Lakers]], Divac got hired as the Lakers' European scout, reporting directly to the team's general manager [[Mitch Kupchak]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/news/story?id=2196445|title=Divac to serve as scout, liaison in Europe|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=19 October 2005|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref> He left the position in 2006.
===Real Madrid Baloncesto club management=== In June 2006, through his friendship with [[Predrag Mijatović]], Divac linked up with [[Ramón Calderón]] as part of the lawyer's candidate bid for the presidency of [[Real Madrid]] [[polideportivo]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://elpais.com/deportes/2006/06/05/actualidad/1149492115_850215.html|title=Calderón presenta su proyecto para el Real Madrid con Mijatovic como director deportivo|agency=''[[El País]]''|date=5 June 2006|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref> When Calderón closely won the club elections on 2 July 2006, Divac was announced as the head of operations at [[Real Madrid Baloncesto|Real Madrid]] basketball club though the scope of his job description soon got reduced to consulting duties as president Calderón's adviser for basketball and club's international coordinator.<ref name="elmundo">{{cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/elmundodeporte/2008/04/02/baloncesto/1207128247.html|title=El increíble caso de Vlade Divac|agency=''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]''|date=4 April 2008|accessdate=10 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://elpais.com/deportes/2006/09/22/actualidad/1158909714_850215.html|title=Divac llega al Real Madrid como "asesor" y con el "gran reto de traer la NBA a Europa"|agency=''[[El País]]''|date=22 September 2006|accessdate=10 July 2018}}</ref>
However, Divac's role in the club's day-to-day operations turned out to be largely symbolic, and he even admitted as much in a March 2007 interview for Croatian weekly ''[[Globus (weekly)|Globus]]'': "I literally do nothing and I only serve as part of the ''royal club'''s image. I only accepted the job because of Mijatović, who is currently the football director at Real".<ref name="mondo">{{cite web |url=http://mondo.rs/a52680/Sport/Kosarka/Divac-Kandidovacu-se-za-predsednika-Srbije.html |title=Divac: Kandidovaću se za predsednika Srbije |publisher=MONDO web portal |language=Serbian |date=8 March 2007 }}</ref> By the end of 2007, following a financial settlement between the two parties, Divac moved on from the post for which he had been reportedly receiving an annual compensation of [[€]]300,000.<ref name="elmundo"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sport.es/es/noticias/futbol/vlade-divac-cobro-300000-euros-por-no-hacer-nada-5822564|title=Vlade Divac cobró 300.000 euros por no hacer nada|agency=Sport.es|date=14 July 2008|accessdate=10 July 2018}}</ref>
===Serbian Deputy Prime Minister's adviser=== In October 2008, Divac's [[political consulting|political advisory]] engagement within the [[Cabinet of Mirko Cvetković|Serbian government]] as the sports, [[diaspora]], and humanitarian advisor to the [[Deputy Prime Minister of Serbia|Deputy Prime Minister]] and [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Serbia)|Internal Affairs Minister]] [[Ivica Dačić]], got announced.<ref>{{cite news|last=J.|first=Ž.|url=https://www.blic.rs/vesti/politika/divac-dobija-kancelariju-u-vladi/gvxrmfk|title=Divac dobija kancelariju u Vladi|agency=''[[Blic]]''|date=17 October 2008|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/basketball/2008/10/16/vlade_divac_appointed_adviser_to_serbia.html|title=Vlade Divac appointed adviser to Serbia|agency=''[[Toronto Star]]''|date=16 October 2008|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Carr|first=Janis|url=https://www.ocregister.com/2008/10/16/divac-playing-new-role/|title=Divac playing new role|agency=''[[Orange County Register]]''|date=16 October 2008|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref>
===Olympic Committee of Serbia president=== Divac was proposed in 2000 as Yugoslavia's candidate for the Sport Commission of the International Olympic Committee in spring 2000. This candidature was withdrawn under pressure from Milošević regime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vreme.com/arhiva_html/490/03.html|title=Apel "Vremena" H.A. Samaranu|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2017}}</ref> In February 2009, Divac ran for presidency of the [[Olympic Committee of Serbia]] against incumbent president [[Ivan Ćurković]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blic.rs/sports.php?id=3867 |title=Curkovic backs Divac bid |publisher=[[Blic]] |date=2009-02-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090215120515/http://www.blic.rs/sports.php?id=3867 |archivedate=2009-02-15 |df= }}</ref> He won the race after Ćurković withdrew just before the scheduled voting.<ref name="blicokserb" /> In November 2012, he was re-elected as the sole candidate; the end of his second mandate coincides with the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] in Rio de Janeiro.<ref name=oks/>
In December 2014, [[Kosovo]] was accepted as a full member of the [[International Olympic Committee]]. Divac and the Serbian Olympic Committee have been criticised, chiefly by the [[Democratic Party of Serbia]], for failing to take any effort to prevent that.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtv.rs/sr_lat/politika/dss-da-li-je-divac-pokusao-da-spreci-ulazak-kosova-u-mok_547452.html |title=DSS: Da li je Divac pokušao da spreči ulazak Kosova u MOK |publisher=Radio Television of Vojvodina |date=2014-12-14 |language=Serbian}}</ref> Divac stated that he is not happy with the decision of the IOC, but could not have prevented it as it had already been made, and said he would accept it "in the interest of the athletes".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2014/12/09/olympics-kosovo-idINKBN0JN10S20141209 |title=Kosovo earns Olympic recognition, Serbia furious |agency=Reuters |date=December 10, 2014 |author=Karolos Grohmann}}</ref>
On May 9, 2017, he was succeeded by Serbian former basketball coach [[Božidar Maljković]] on position of the president of [[Olympic Committee of Serbia]].<ref>[http://sport.blic.rs/ostali-sportovi/bozidar-maljkovic-novi-predsednik-olimpijskog-komiteta-srbije/ws3p3fb Božidar Maljković novi predsednik Olimpijskog komiteta Srbije!]</ref>
===Sacramento Kings front office=== ====Initial advisory role==== In early March 2015, Divac was hired by the [[Sacramento Kings]] as their vice president of basketball and franchise operations.<ref name="divac-kings-march2015">{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/kings/2015/03/03/vlade-divac-sacramento-vice-president-basketball-franchise-operations-george-karl/24326819/ |title=Kings hire Vlade Divac as vice president, adviser |work=USA Today Sports |date=2015-03-03 |author=Adi Joseph}}</ref> Brought into the organization by the principal owner [[Vivek Ranadivé]] towards the end of a turbulent [[2014–15 Sacramento Kings season|season]], Divac's arrival came in the wake of head coach [[Michael Malone (basketball)|Mike Malone]]'s firing and the eventual hiring of [[George Karl]]. Working alongside the team's general manager [[Pete D'Alessandro]], Divac's initial duties with the Kings were reported to be advising the front office and coaches as well as assisting with branding and fan outreach.<ref name="divac-kings-march2015"/> However, such broadly defined job responsibilities immediately led to press speculation about Divac's role within the organization that in addition to general manager D'Alessandro also featured assistant GM [[Mike Bratz]], special assistant to the GM [[Mitch Richmond]], director of player personnel and analytics [[Dean Oliver (statistician)|Dean Oliver]], adviser to the chairman [[Chris Mullin (basketball)|Chris Mullin]], as well as a head coach, Karl, who has always wanted to be involved in personnel issues.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ziller|first=Tom|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2015/3/20/8263149/vivek-ranadive-kings-front-office-warriors-vlade-divac|title=The Kings are trying hard to be the Warriors and failing miserably|agency=[[SB Nation]]|date=20 March 2015|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref> Within a month of Divac's hiring, [[ESPN]]'s [[Marc Stein (reporter)|Marc Stein]] reported that "despite the Kings not yet announcing their new power structure, Divac is indeed already regarded as the team's top basketball official by owner Ranadivé".<ref>{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Marc|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/12644960/vlade-divac-emerges-sacramento-kings-lead-voice|title=Vlade Divac emerges as Kings' lead voice|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=8 April 2015|accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref>
On 10 June 2015, two weeks before the NBA draft, general manager D'Alessandro left the Kings by accepting a front-office position with the Denver Nuggets amid reports he did so due to being stripped of his decision-making power after Ranadivé hired Divac.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jones|first=Jason|url=http://www.sacbee.com/sports/nba/sacramento-kings/kings-blog/article23669575.html|title=Kings general manager Pete D’Alessandro takes job with Nuggets|agency=''[[Sacramento Bee]]''|date=10 June 2015|accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Ziller|first=Tom|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2015/6/11/8764711/sacramento-kings-front-office-vlade-divac-vivek-ranadive|title=The Kings front office is even messier than it appears|agency=[[SB Nation]]|date=11 June 2015|accessdate=15 April 2018}}</ref>
Only days before the draft, animosity between head coach Karl and the team's star center [[DeMarcus Cousins]] reignited, as Karl reportedly lobbied Divac, as well as multiple players on the Kings' roster, in order to make the case to owner Ranadive that Cousins needs to be traded.<ref>{{cite news|last=[[Adrian Wojnarowski|Wojnarowski]]|first=[[Adrian Wojnarowski|Adrian]]|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/sources--george-karl-pushing-for-kings-to-trade-demarcus-cousins-051748948.html|title=Sources: George Karl pushing for Kings to trade DeMarcus Cousins|agency=[[Yahoo Sports]]|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> As a result, against the backdrop of Cousins calling Karl a "snake" on Twitter,<ref>{{cite news|last=Zller|first=Tom|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2015/6/23/8830539/george-karl-snake-demarcus-cousins-history|title=A brief history of NBA stars calling George Karl a snake|agency=[[SB Nation]]|date=23 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> Divac reportedly discussed multiple Cousins trade scenarios with various teams, but ultimately no deal got made.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wojnarowski|first=Adrian|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/sources--kings-talking-to-lakers-about-demarcus-cousins-trade--fielding-offers-from-other-teams-030157845.html|title=Sources: Kings talking to Lakers about DeMarcus Cousins trade, fielding offers from other teams|agency=[[Yahoo Sports]]|date=24 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> At the [[2015 NBA draft]], with the 6th pick, the Kings selected 21-year-old center [[Willie Cauley-Stein]] out of [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|Kentucky]]. Less than a week following the draft, with the dissolution of the Karl—Cousins relationship on public display, the Kings' ultimately unsuccessful attempt at landing University of Kentucky head coach [[John Calipari]] to replace Karl got reported.<ref>{{cite news|last=Wojnarowski|first=Adrian|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/sources--kings--john-calipari--kentucky-195614697.html|title=Sources: Kings probing John Calipari about coaching, front-office jobs|agency=[[Yahoo Sports]]|date=30 June 2015|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref>
Then in early July 2015, in an effort of clearing [[NBA salary cap|salary cap]] space in order to immediately go after [[free agent]]s, they agreed a trade with the Philadelphia 76ers, sending [[Nick Stauskas]], [[Carl Landry]], [[Jason Thompson (basketball)|Jason Thompson]] along with the Kings' future first round draft pick to the Sixers as well as the rights to swap first round picks in 2016 and 2017 while receiving the rights to Sixers oversees players [[Artūras Gudaitis]] and [[Luka Mitrović]] in return.<ref>{{cite news|last=Feldman|first=Dan|url=https://nba.nbcsports.com/2015/07/01/76ers-get-nik-stauskas-in-salary-dump-trade-with-kings/|title=76ers get Nik Stauskas, first-rounder in salary-dump trade with Kings|agency=[[NBC Sports]]|date=1 July 2015|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref> Two days later, they agreed the acquisitions of two free agents: twenty-nine-year-old [[Marco Belinelli]] on a three-year US$19 million contract and twenty-nine-year-old point guard [[Rajon Rondo]] for one year for US$10 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Herbert|first=James|url=https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/rajon-rondo-kings-agree-to-1-year-10-million-deal/|title=Rajon Rondo, Kings agree to 1-year, $10 million deal |agency=[[CBSSports.com]]|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref> This was followed by signing twenty-six-year-old center [[Kosta Koufos]] for four years and US$33 million with his role envisioned as backup for Cousins.<ref>{{cite news|last=Golliver|first=Ben|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2015/07/07/kosta-koufos-sacramento-kings-free-agency-grades-demarcus-cousins|title=Grade the deal: Kings cap strange summer by signing Kosta Koufos|agency=[[SI.com]]|date=7 July 2015|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
With the free agent signings done, Divac turned his attention to attempting to mend the relations between the team's head coach Karl and its star center Cousins ahead of the 2015-16 season, admitting publicly on 9 July 2015 on [[CBS Sports Radio]]'s ''[[The Jim Rome Show]]'' that the relationship between the two "isn't pretty right now".<ref>{{cite news|author=ESPN.com news services|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/13229088/vlade-divac-sacramento-kings-george-karl-demarcus-cousins-union-not-pretty-right-now|title=Vlade Divac working to make Karl-Cousins relationship better|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=9 July 2015|accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref> A few days later, on 13 July 2015, during a [[2015 NBA Summer League]] game in [[Las Vegas]], the two shared an awkward on-camera handshake as Karl approached and Cousins reluctantly shook the coach's hand before turning away.<ref>{{cite news|author=ESPN.com news services|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Sports/kings-coach-george-karl-demarcus-cousins-share-awkward/story?id=32439225|title=Kings coach George Karl, DeMarcus Cousins share awkward handshake|agency=[[Abcnews.go.com]]|date=14 July 2015|accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref><ref name="voisin-april-2016">{{cite news|last=Voisin|first=Ailene|url=https://www.sacbee.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/ailene-voisin/article74937347.html|title=George Karl reflective after firing by Kings|agency=''[[Sacramento Bee]]''|date=30 April 2016|accessdate=8 July 2018}}</ref> Later that week, Divac summoned Cousins and Karl to a private counseling session.<ref name="voisin-april-2016"/>
====Promotion to general manager==== Divac was promoted to the Kings' vice president of basketball operations and general manager on 31 August 2015.<ref name="divac-gm">{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/kings/new/kings-announce-basketball-operations-update|title=Kings Announce Basketball Operations Update|work=NBA.com|publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc.|date=August 31, 2015|accessdate=August 31, 2015}}</ref>
Amid a tense<ref>{{cite news|author=ESPN.com news services|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/16185384/rajon-rondo-tension-filled-sacramento-kings-never-jelled-team|title=Rajon Rondo details Kings' woes, sends thoughts to Orlando|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=14 June 2016|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> and incident-filled<ref>{{cite news|author=''Slam'' staff|url=https://www.slamonline.com/uncategorized/demarcus-cousins-reportedly-cursed-out-george-karl-monday-night/|title=DeMarcus Cousins Reportedly Cursed Out George Karl Monday Night|agency=''[[Slam (magazine)|Slam]]''|date=11 November 2015|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> [[2015–16 Sacramento Kings season|season]] that saw the team briefly reach the final [[2016 NBA Playoffs|playoff]] spot in the [[Western Conference (NBA)|Western Conference]] before unravelling with extended losing streaks in late January and early February 2016, the organization reportedly made a decision to fire their head coach George Karl during the upcoming [[2016 NBA All-Star Game|All-Star break]], a move pushed for by Divac.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Marc|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/14744059/sacramento-kings-planning-fire-coach-george-karl-coming-days|title=Sources: Kings planning to fire coach George Karl in coming days|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=9 February 2016|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> However, in a quick about-face, Karl got retained after meeting with Divac and reportedly pledging to make changes to address concerns within the organization about his defensive schemes and practice policies.<ref>{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Marc|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/14747006/sacramento-kings-retain-george-karl-coach|title=Kings to retain George Karl after meeting with Vlade Divac|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=9 February 2016|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> It was later reported that the move to fire Karl on this occasion got scuttled by the Kings minority owners over financial concerns.<ref name="Kings-fire-Karl">{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Marc|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/15203663/sacramento-kings-fire-coach-george-karl|title=Kings fire George Karl|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> Month and a half later, in late March 2016, Divac signed a multi-year contract extension with the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/nba/story/_/id/15097196/sacramento-kings-extend-contract-vp-vlade-divac |title=Kings extend contract of VP Vlade Divac |publisher=[[ESPN.com]] |date=2016-03-30 |author=[[Marc Stein (reporter)|Marc Stein]]}}</ref> The team finished the season 33–49, eight games out of the playoffs, good for 10th spot in the Western Conference. Their final season in [[Sleep Train Arena]], the team's home since 1988, it was also their first 30 plus win campaign after seven consecutive seasons of fewer than 30 wins.
Early into the team's off-season, in mid April 2016, the Kings organization fired head coach George Karl, a decision made by Divac who had reportedly been pushing for it for months.<ref name="Kings-fire-Karl"/> Within three weeks, during which Divac interviewed head coaching candidates [[Sam Mitchell (basketball)|Sam Mitchell]], [[Vinny Del Negro]], [[Mike Woodson]], [[David Blatt]], [[Mark Jackson (basketball)|Mark Jackson]], [[Jeff Hornacek]], [[Nate McMillan]], [[Patrick Ewing]], [[Elston Turner]], and [[Corliss Williamson]],<ref name="Joerger-hired">{{cite news|author=ESPN.com news services|url=http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/15494387/sacramento-kings-dave-joerger-agree-four-year-deal|title=Dave Joerger agrees to four-year deal to coach Kings|agency=[[ESPN.com]]|date=10 May 2016|accessdate=23 June 2018}}</ref> the Kings hired [[Dave Joerger]] as their new head coach, signing him to a four-year deal worth [[US$]]16 million.<ref name="Joerger-hired"/> At the [[2016 NBA draft]], with the 8th pick, the Kings selected [[Marquese Chriss]] out of the [[Washington Huskies men's basketball|University of Washington]], but traded him to the [[Phoenix Suns]] for rights to [[Bogdan Bogdanović (basketball)|Bogdan Bogdanović]] as well as the Suns' 2016 draft 13th and 28th picks, [[Georgios Papagiannis]] and [[Skal Labissière]], respectively.
At the [[2017 NBA draft]], with the 5th pick, the Kings selected point guard [[De'Aaron Fox]] out of [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|Kentucky]].
==Investments== Divac has been involved in many non-basketball endeavors while still actively playing in the [[National Basketball Association|NBA]], and more so after he retired. He is an active restaurant investor in the [[Sacramento, California]] area. However, his attempts to make major investments in Serbia failed, for a variety of reasons.
The most notable affair was a highly publicized business venture—takeover bid of profitable beverage producer [[Knjaz Miloš]]. Divac's company "Apurna", in a joint venture with French dairy giant [[Danone]], ostensibly proposed the best bid, but the takeover was aborted by the Serbia's Securities Commission, because Danone/Apurna allegedly offered extra money to small shareholders.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://cee-foodindustry.com/news/ng.asp?id=56547&n=wh49&c=%23emailcode |title=Knjaz Milos auction descends into chaos |publisher=CEE-foodindustry.com |date=2004-12-03 |accessdate=2007-09-25 |author=Chris Mercer}}</ref> In the repeated bid, Divac and Danone eventually withdrew and the sale went to [[FPP Balkan Ltd.]], a privatization fund from the [[Cayman Islands]]. The entire messy affair caused great friction within the [[Serbian government]], wide speculation about corruption, resignation of the Securities Commission chief, and even a police investigation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cee-foodindustry.com/news/ng.asp?id=56659-danone-pulls-out |title=Danone pulls out of Serbian soft drink bidding race |publisher=CEE-foodindustry.com |date=2004-12-08 |accessdate=2007-09-25 |author=Chris Mercer}}</ref>
Another similar, though less spectacular, episode happened with 2005 Divac's attempt to take over the ''[[Večernje novosti]]'', a Serbian high-circulation daily.<ref>{{cite web |title=Država preigrala Divca |url=http://www.nuns.org.yu/dosije/18/10.jsp |author=Vera Didanović |publisher=nuns.org |date=2006-01-03 |accessdate=2009-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091228181340/http://www.nuns.org.yu/dosije/18/10.jsp |archivedate=2009-12-28 |df= }}</ref> He made an agreement with small shareholders to take over the company by means of registering a new company with joint capital, which would increase the share capital. However, the Serbian Government intervened and halted what should have been a mere technical move. While the attempted takeover was a "backdoor" one indeed, it was legal and similar cases had already occurred. The government ostensibly feared lack of control over the influential daily. Even though the [[Supreme Court of Serbia]] eventually ruled in Divac's favor, he withdrew from the contest, citing "friendly advice" by unnamed persons.<ref>{{cite web |title=NBA ace Vlade Divac slam dunks the Serbian government |url=http://www.setimes.com/cocoon/setimes/xhtml/en_GB/features/setimes/features/2006/07/06/feature-02 |author=Georgi Mitev-Shantek |publisher=Southeast European Times |date=2006-07-06 |accessdate=2007-09-25}}</ref> Embittered, he decided to stop his attempts to invest in Serbia: "All of this is ugly and I'm very upset... I realized that there's no place for me in Serbia and my friends can meet me in Madrid from now on... In Serbia, some different rules are in effect, and I can't conceive them".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dnevnik.rs/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=12484 |title=Vukčević: Dijaspora će zapamtiti kako je prošao Divac |publisher=[[Dnevnik (Novi Sad)]] |language=Serbian |date=2006-07-21 |accessdate=2007-09-25 |author=Lj. Malešević}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
However, that turned out not to be true, as in October 2007 Divac got legally registered as 100% owner of [[Voda Voda]], a [[bottled water]] brand previously owned by businessman [[Vojin Đorđević]]. That transaction was also followed by a stir of controversy, as Đorđević publicly accused Divac of deceit, asserting that he broke a [[gentlemen's agreement]] they had, and questioning the validity of the contract that Divac presented to the [[Serbian Business Registers Agency]]. The circumstances surrounding the deal (as of November 2007) are still unclear: Divac claims that he indeed loaned some money to the Đorđević's [[Si&Si]] company, which was in financial troubles, and after Đorđević failed to fulfill his part of the deal, just used the contract, already properly signed by Đorđević, to claim ownership of the company.<ref name="politika">{{cite web |url=http://www.blic.co.rs/infocus.php?id=947 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130416121130/http://www.blic.co.rs/infocus.php?id=947 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-04-16 |title='You are insulting me while you have debts' |date=2007-10-31 |publisher=[[Blic]] |accessdate=2007-11-05 }}</ref><ref name="b92voda">{{cite web |url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/business-article.php?yyyy=2007&mm=11&dd=02&nav_id=45059 |title=Government to intervene in Voda Voda feud |date=2007-11-02 |publisher=[[B92]] |accessdate=2007-11-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071107103443/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/business-article.php?yyyy=2007&mm=11&dd=02&nav_id=45059 |archivedate=2007-11-07 |df= }}</ref>
==Humanitarian work== [[Image:Vlade Divac.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Vlade Divac (rear, center) alongside Crown Prince [[Alexander, Crown Prince of Yugoslavia|Alexander II]] in 2005, at an event for [[World Heart Federation|World Heart Day]]]] Divac is a humanitarian worker, focusing on aid to children worldwide and refugees in his home country. Along with six Serbian basketball teammates, Divac established the charity called [[Group Seven]], later renamed to "Divac's Children Foundation", and works closely with [[International Orthodox Christian Charities]] (IOCC), helping them to raise around US$500,000 for humanitarian assistance in Serbia since 1997.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://divac.com/aboutus.html |title=About us |publisher=Divac's Children Foundation |accessdate=2007-09-25}}</ref> Divac's own foundation, presided by his wife Snežana, provided over $2,500,000 in humanitarian assistance through 1998–2007.<ref name="nba">{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/news/divac_youcantoo_070922.html |title=Divac Creates New Team With "You Can Too" Campaign |publisher=[[NBA.com]] |date=2007-09-22 |accessdate=2007-09-25}}</ref>
In late 2007 Divac founded a humanitarian organization, "You Can Too" ([[Serbian language|Serbian]]: ''Можеш и ти/Možeš i ti''), bent on assisting the refugees in Serbia. Serbia has around 500,000 refugees from the 1990s [[Yugoslav wars]], making it the country with the largest refugee problem in Europe.<ref name="nba" /> Around 7,800 of those people still live in collective centers under poor conditions, so the organization has vouched itself to buy abandoned countryside houses, in an attempt to finally solve their accommodation problem.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.b92.net/sport/kosarka/kosarka.php?yyyy=2007&mm=09&dd=21&nav_id=264626 |title=Divac za 7.850 izbeglica |publisher=[[B92]] |language=Serbian |date=2007-09-23 |accessdate=2007-09-25}}</ref>
From September 21 to 23, 2007, Divac organized an official farewell from active basketball career in his hometown Prijepolje and Belgrade, simultaneously promoting the "You Can Too" campaign. The spectacle culminated in gathering of Divac and his worldwide friends in front of 10,000 people outside the [[National Assembly of Serbia|National Assembly]] building.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.b92.net/sport/kosarka/kosarka.php?yyyy=2007&mm=09&dd=23&nav_id=264726 |title=Spektakularni oproštaj Divca |publisher=[[B92]] |language=Serbian |date=2007-09-23 |accessdate=2007-09-25}}</ref>
==In popular culture== In the early 1990s, the song "Vlade Divac" by Belgrade band [[Deca Loših Muzičara]], devoted to his transfer to Lakers, was a big hit; the band finally got to personally meet Divac and perform the song with him on his farewell party in 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arhiva.kurir-info.rs/Arhiva/2007/septembar/22/ST-06-22092007.shtml |title=Deca Loših Muzičara pevaju za Divca! |publisher=[[Kurir]] |date=2007-09-22 |accessdate=2007-09-25}}</ref>
During his time with the Lakers, Divac's popularity and marketing potential, in addition to his entertaining and good-natured personality, were picked up on by the American TV industry. As a result, he appeared quite a few times on Los Angeles-based late night programmes such as ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]'' and ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]''. In 1990, he was featured in a commercial with Laker teammates [[A. C. Green]] and [[Mychal Thompson]] for the [[Schick (razors)|Schick]] brand razors company.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bCTx6K3Irag |title=1990 – Schick – Vlade Divac, A.C. Green, Mychal Thompson |publisher=YouTube |date=2008-09-05 |accessdate=2013-01-24}}</ref> He also appeared in American [[sitcom]]s ''[[Married... with Children]]'' and ''[[Coach (TV series)|Coach]]'', as well as in the short lived ''[[Good Sports]]'' sitcom. On the big screen Divac took part in basketball-based movies ''[[Eddie (film)|Eddie]]'', ''[[Space Jam]]'' and ''[[Juwanna Mann]]''. Later in his career, he appeared on ''[[Larry King Live]]'' in 1999 and ''[[The Late Late Show (CBS TV series)|The Late Late Show]]'' in 2002.
In Serbia, all throughout his playing career, Divac regularly appeared in commercials pitching products ranging from Atlas Beer to [[Société Générale Yugoslav Bank|Société Générale Bank]] mortgage credit plans. He appeared in a national TV commercial in the United States alongside former NBA star [[Darryl Dawkins]] for [[Taco Bell]].
Divac appeared as a special guest on [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008|Eurovision 2008]]. He threw a ball into the audience, which marked the beginning of [[televoting]].
Divac features in the [[ESPN]] ''[[30 for 30]]'' documentary ''[[Once Brothers]]'', where he discusses the exploits of the [[Yugoslavia national basketball team]] in the late 1980s and early 1990s and how the Yugoslav Wars tore them apart, especially in context of his broken friendship with Croatian player [[Dražen Petrović]].<ref name=once/>
Divac appears in [[Boris Malagurski]]'s documentary film ''[[The Weight of Chains]]'', in which he talks about the 1999 [[NATO bombing of Yugoslavia]].
==Personal life== Divac and his wife, Snežana, have two sons, Luka and Matija, and an adopted daughter, Petra, whose biological parents were killed by [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] snipers during the [[Kosovo War]].<ref name="si-may1999-Rick Reilly"/>
